Harley thought there should be a central office staff. Siegel argued that
he could do these shows for half the cost. Hull suggested that shortcuts be
used wherever possible. Harley stated that he had been guided by what he
understood to be the principle of operation outlined by the committee: ,fGet
the best minds; and the consultant is God.” He felt that the distinctive
feature of the programs was their authenticity and the authority behind them.
Siegel said that he had no criticism of the past, but that he wanted the
uneconomic procedures of the past eliminated. What he had been saying was
intended as advice for the future. Probst said that he was not sure that
losses could be avoided when you attempt to transfigure an academician into
a radio dramatist. Probst said his experience was that a content-matter
specialist and a scriptwriter alone are not enough to work with a consultant,
for the decisions of the producer are a necessary element.
Hull stated that he felt we should keep the committee discussions at the policy
level. He had only expressed an opinion that the costs are alarmingly high,
but the ends may well justify the costs. Hull used as an analogy the idea that
he could hire Wons to conduct some audience surveys for WOI-TV at 25$ an
interview. He didn’t think he’d learn much from such a survey. He could also
get Won3 to conduct a survey at $5-00 an interview. This would certainly be
more revealing and tell him more of what he wanted to know. At the present
time a research group on the Iox*a State College campus was conducting some
interviews at $25.00 each. From this Hull was getting what he wanted to know,
but thought the cost was exorbitant. Certainly there is some middle ground
between the $5*00 and the $25.00 figures.
Probst said that he had felt that the costs were high, but that now he had
seen a few of the Jefferson scripts and the high quality which had been ob¬
tained, he felt that the situation could be justified and defended. Further,
it must always be kept in mind that the preliminary fumbling and uncertainties
were avoided in the later productions.
At this point Harley reported on a feeler he had received from the Iron and
Steel Institute. The tentative idea is that they would make albums of the
entire Jefferson series and make them available to schools. Probst thought
that this was wonderful and would strengthen our hand with Fletcher and
Fletcher’s hand with his Board. Probst pointed out that with all its money
the Saudek TV-Radio Workshop group had been unable to sell any of its work.
If we could pull off this deal it would support Fletcher’s conviction that
he was right in insisting on continuing support of educational radio work.
Probst asked what should be the conditions of our acceptance of such an offer
as had come from the Iron and Steel Institute. What credits should the Insti¬
tute get and what costs should they bear? Siegel said that they could cer¬
tainly eliminate the cost of distribution to NAEB stations. Probst thought
we should keep in mind the effect of this proposal on Fletcher. Siegel pro¬
posed that the Institute should pay the NAEB a nominal fee, that they put in
a minimum of advertising material, and that they give the NAEB 100 copies for
distribution to its members.
